question: In the future, nobody will buy printed newspapers or books because they will be able to read everything they want online without paying. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?
text: Some people believe that the sales of publications such as books or newspapers will be left behind because they could get it free through the internet. As a response to that statement, I would like to demonstrate my disagreement.

Nowadays, the use of technology has grown rapidly in many sectors, including  publications. Consequently, it is now becoming a trend that people are more likely to gain some information through digital platforms rather than printed materials. However, the alteration of reading habits from real paper to online does not mean that the readers could have  access for free. For instance, several publishers such as Cambridge or Pearson have built a system where people can purchase their products online and read them directly by their exclusive platform. By this, people still need to pay in order to read some books or newspapers.

Besides some publishers having established web-based services for their business, it is also important to acknowledge the work of the authors. It is collectively believed that writing is a challenging activity that requires a lot of hard work. Therefore, people should give  honour to the writers by purchasing their products from the official markets. It might be true that people could obtain some paid publications for free from illegal websites such as libgen or sci-hub. Nonetheless, this activity is rather unethical and does not show any respect to the authors.

In conclusion, despite the changes in the publication's products from print to digital, people should still pay if they want to get access since the publishers have established the environment for online reading as well as the acknowledgement for the authors.
